Interesting, thanks Charles.  So if you get a novel game and right 
away ne=
ed to play it with no prior experience, how can an 
evolutionary system be =
prepared for that?  Are you trying to evolve 
a single neural network that =
can play any game?  I'm still unclear 
how this can be accomplished.

ken

=

> Accord=
ing to the competition's site(please correct me if I'm 
wrong!)

pplication functions over a network, your program connects to

ter who picks the game that will be played and transmits
> the game definit=
ion to the program, the game is then played (some 
are
> 1,2, or more playe=
rs) and the GameMaster program decides a score at
> the end of the game bas=
ed on the game rules.  Before your match 
you do
> not know what game you w=
ill be playing, and for the competition 
they
> will add new games that hav=
en't been release so people can't just
> program for all the different game=
s.  During the weeks of the
> competition you are allows( and encouraged) t=
o make changes to your
> application for the next week's matches.  The play=
 clock can vary 
from
> between 10 seconds and an hour.  This year they pla=
n to have a 
pretty
> large range of the clocks.  If you don't make a move =
the GameMaster
> will for you, if you make an illegal move, the GameMaster =
will 
make a
> move for you and you get a score of 0 for the match.
> 
> So=
 the short answer I believe is "Yes, it is plug and play.". :-)

> Charle=
